Description: A draped woman standing to front, pointing to left, her head tilted down to right, study for a painting (?) Pen and brown ink Turner and Plazzotta 1991 Her body is turned slightly to the left, but her head leans back to the right; she wears a flowing garment and some of her drapery billows out behind her to the right.
Curator's comments: This could be a study for an angel leading Lot and his family out of Sodom, as the old mount suggested. Turner and Plazzotta 1991 Although no painting of this exact subject is known, the iconography suggested in the lost inscription seems plausible enough. A similarly posed figure sometimes occurs in Guercino's work, for example in the following instances: in the distance in the 'Rest on the Flight into Egypt', a copy of which is in the Martin d'Arcy Gallery of Art, Loyola University, Chicago (Salerno, 1988, no. 153); the 'St Michael' in S. Nicola, Fabriano (Salerno, 1988, no. 216); and the angel in the 'Calling of the Blessed Luigi Gonzaga', in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York (Salerno, 1988, no. 276). Literature: Salerno, I Dipinti del Guercino, Rome 1988.
Bibliographic references: Turner & Plazzotta 1991 / Drawings by Guercino from British Collections (App.22)
